awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a 400 MHz Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) for Research at Arkansas State University
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) and Chemical Research Instrumentation programs.  Arkansas State University is acquiring a 400 MHz nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectrometer that has the capabilities to perform both routine analysis and more complex experiments to help elucidate molecular structures of chemical compounds. The instrument supports the research of Professor M. Abrar Alam and colleagues Fabricio Medina-Bolivar, Hashim Ali, John Hershberger and Allyn Ontko.  The spectrometer allows research in a variety of fields such as developing synthetic methodologies to synthesize scaffolds and molecules having potential biological activity, and studying biosynthetic pathways of plant-based stilbenoids.  In general, Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution or in the solid state. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry.  Students from local high schools and student participating in on-campus research programs for underrepresented minorities also benefit from using this state of the art equipment.

The award of the NMR spectrometer is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels.  It especially impacts the development of methodologies to facilitate the structure elucidation of small and medium-sized molecules.  The instrumentation is also used to study persistent emerging organic contaminants and polymeric asphalt binders.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This MRI grant helped to acquire 1D and 2D NMR data for ~1,000 novel compounds, which helped to publish several papers over the grant period and many paers will bepublished soon. Some of the important papers are the following. These compounds contains two major classes of heterocycles, pyrazole and fused thiazole. Pyrazole derivatives potent antibacterial aget with selective activity against methicillin-resistant bacteria. Several of the thiazole derivatives are antineoplastic agents. 

  1. Roy, S.; Budhathoki, S.; Alam, M. A. Synthesis of Thiazole-Fused Diosgenin Derivatives as Potential Therapeutic Agents. ChemistrySelect 2024, 9 (40), e202402485. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1002/slct.202402485.
  2. Roy, S.; Budhathoki, S.; Iqbal, A. D.; Erickson, A. N.; Ali, M. A.; Alam, M. A. Domino Reaction Protocol to Synthesize Benzothiophene-Derived Chemical Entities as Potential Therapeutic Agents. J. Org. Chem., 2024, 89 (6), 3781-3799. DOI: 10.1021/acs.joc.3c02646.
  3. Roy, S.; Raj, H. KC.; Adhikary, S.; Erickson, A. N.; Alam, M. A. Efficient Synthesis of Thiazole-fused Bisnoralcohol Derivatives as Potential Therapeutic Agents. ACS Omega 2024, 9, 22, 23283–23293. https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acsomega.3c09721
  4. Roy, S.; Kc, H. R.; Roberts, J.; Hastings, J.; Gilmore, D. F.; Shields, R. C.; Alam, M. A., Development and Antibacterial Properties of 4-[4-(Anilinomethyl)-3-phenylpyrazol-1-yl]benzoic Acid Derivatives as Fatty Acid Biosynthesis Inhibitors. J. Med. Chem. 2023, 66 (19), 13622-13645
  5. Nisar, R.; Adhikary, S.; Ahmad, S.; Alam*, M. A. In Vitro Antimelanoma Properties of Verbena officinalis Fractions. Molecules2022, 27 (19), 6329. https://doi.org/10.3390/molecules27196329

Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Mohammad A Alam

Image
  • The image shows the artistic description of a novel pyrazole-derived compound with a Gram-positive bacterium. The image has been highlighted as one of the cover papes of the Journal of Medicinal chemistry.
    Jornal of Medicinal Chemistry
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Mohammad A Alam
    Interation of prazole compounds against Gram-positive bacteria
